TemplateInfo.Name: UKMOD Statistics - Default
TemplateInfo.Title: UKMOD Statistics - Default
TemplateInfo.Subtitle: Results for [baseSysPretty]
TemplateInfo.GeneralDescription:
Income concepts:

Market/Original incomes are the sum of income from employment and self-employment plus income from other sources. Other sources of market income include income from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, and income of children younger than 16, minus private transfers paid to other households.

All analyses of disposable income are presented on two bases: Before Housing Costs (BHC) and After Housing Costs (AHC).

Disposable income BHC is the sum of market incomes and benefits (incl. pensions) minus taxes and national insurance contributions.

Disposable income AHC equals disposable income BHC minus housing costs, where housing costs are from the Households Below Average Income (HBAI) micro-data. Housing costs include: rent (gross of housing benefit); water rates; community water charges and council water charges; mortgage interest payments; structural insurance premiums.

Equivalised household (benefit unit) disposable income is the total disposable income of the household (benefit unit) divided by the OECD scale (modified OECD scale), rescaled to a couple without children following the HBAI approach. The benefit unit is the nuclear family - the couple (cohabiting or married) or single adult plus any dependent children. For Before Housing Costs income, the equivalence scale attributes a weight of 0.67 to the head of the household/benefit unit, a weight of 0.33 to any other member aged 14 years or over, and a weight of 0.2 to every child aged under 14 years. For After Housing Costs income, the equivalence scale attributes a weight of 0.58 to the head of the household/benefit unit, 0.42 to any other member aged 14 years or over, and a weight of 0.2 for any child aged under 14 years.

Decile groups are calculated by ranking individuals according to their equivalised household (benefit unit) disposable income – either BHC or AHC – and dividing them into ten similar-sized groups. Some variation in the size of population deciles can arise due to the condition that all income units with the same equivalised income appear in the same decile group.

All monetary amounts - except for the fiscal overview - are presented in average weekly amounts and in GBP (i.e. in the currency defined for the UKMOD output file).

The unit of analysis is the individual, so the populations and percentages in the tables are numbers and percentages of individuals.

Poverty indicators:

Households are defined as being at risk of poverty (poor) if their equivalised household disposable income is below the poverty line. The poverty line is defined as 60% of the country specific median equivalised household disposable income in currency per week. The poverty gap is the difference between the poverty line and the median income of people at-risk-of poverty divided by the poverty line. The median income of people at-risk-of poverty is based on equivalised household disposable income per week.

NOTE: negative equivalised household disposable incomes are recoded to 0 for all poverty related results.

Inequality indicators:

Gini index measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

The S80/20 ratio - also referred to as the income quintile share ratio - is the ratio of the total income received by the 20% of the population with the highest income to that received by the bottom 20%.

NOTE: negative incomes are recoded to 0 for results on Gini and S80/20 indicators.

Definition of age-groups:

Sub-population groups are defined as follows:

·    Children are defined as being under 16 or under 20 years old and in full-time non-advanced education and not married.

·    Elderly are persons aged 65 or older

·    Adults are defined as anyone who is not a child and not an elderly (i.e. being aged 16 or above, or 20 or above if full-time non-advanced education and not married, and up to the age of 64)

·    Someone is in work if he/she has income from employment or self-employment

 

The income concepts used throughout and the corresponding UKMOD variables are as follows

Disposable income BHC: ils_dispy = ils_origy + ils_ben – ils_tax – ils_sicdy (ils_sicer not reported as income)

Disposable income AHC: il_dispy_ahc = ils_dispy – xhc_hbai

Total market income: ils_origy = ils_earns + other sources of market income

Employment and self-employment income: ils_earns = yem + yse

Employment income: yem

Self-employment income: yse

Other sources of market income: yiy + yot01 + ypr + ypp + yptot + yptmp - xmp - tpcee_s

Investment income: yiy

Income from odd jobs: yot01

Property income: ypr

Personal pension: ypp

Private transfers (non-taxable): yptot

Received maintenance payment: yptmp

Maintenance paid: xmp

Employee private compulsory pension contributions: tpcee_s

Government revenue through direct taxes and national insurance contributions: ils_tax + ils_sicdy + ils_sicer

Direct taxes: ils_tax = ils_taxsim + i_bmu_tmu

Personal income tax: ils_taxsim = tin_s = tin12_s + tin11_s + tin00_s

Devolved taxes in Scotland: tin12_s

Devolved taxes in Wales: tin11_s

Non-devolved taxes: tin00_s = i_tin_rUK_NSND + i_tin_sav + i_tin_div

Non-devolved non-saving non-dividend taxes: i_tin_rUK_NSND

Non-devolved saving income taxes: i_tin_sav

Non-devolved dividend income taxes: i_tin_div

Council tax: i_bmu_tmu

All national insurance contributions: ils_sicdy + ils_sicer

National insurance contributions (personal): ils_sicdy = ils_sicee + ils_sicse + ils_sicot

Employee national insurance contributions: ils_sicee = tscee_s

Self-employed national insurance contributions: ils_sicse = tscse_s

Other national insurance contributions (non-existent in the UK): ils_sicot

National insurance contributions (employer): ils_sicer = tscer_s

Indirect taxes: il_tco_tall = il_tco_tv + il_tco_ta + il_tco_tt

Ad valorem excise: il_tco_tv

Specific excise: il_tco_ta

Value Added Tax: il_tco_tt

Credited national insurance contributions: ils_sicct = tscct_s

Government expenditure on benefits and tax credits: ils_ben = ils_benmt + ils_bennt + ils_pen

Means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_benmt = bsauc_s - brduc_s + bunmt_s + bsa_s + bsadi_s + boamt_s + bmu_s + bho_s - brd_s + bwkmt_s + bfamt_s + bmamt_s + bmamt01_s + bmascmt_s + bch_s + bchmt_s + bchmt01_s + bmascmt01_s + bched01_s + bched02_s + bhosc01_s + bsaec_s

Universal Credit: bsauc_s

Benefit cap (reducing Universal Credit): brduc_s

Income-based Jobseeker's Allowance: bunmt_s

Income Support not simulated elsewhere: bsa_s

Income-related Employment and Support Allowance: bsadi_s

Pension Credit: boamt_s

Council Tax Benefit/Reduction: bmu_s

Housing Benefit: bho_s

Benefit cap (reducing Housing Benefit): brd_s

Working Tax Credit: bwkmt_s

Child Tax Credit: bfamt_s

Sure Start Maternity Grant: bmamt_s

Healthy Start (food) voucher: bmamt01_s

Best Start Grant (Scotland, from 2019): bmascmt_s

Child benefit: bch_s

Scottish Child Payment (including bridging, from 2020): bchmt_s + bchmt01_s

Best Start foods (Scotland, from 2020): bmascmt01_s

Free School meals (from 2017): bched01_s

School clothing grant (from 2017): bched02_s

Discretionary Housing Payments (Scotland, from 2017): bhosc01_s

Cost of Living Payment (selected years): bsaec_s

Non-means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_bennt = simulated non-means-tested non-pension benefits + non-simulated non-means-tested non-pension benefits

simulated non-means-tested non-pension benefits: bmact_s + bmanc_s + bpact_s + boaht_s + bunct_s + bchht_s + bcrdicm_s + bwkmcee_s + bwkmcse_s

Statutory Maternity Pay: bmact_s

Maternity Allowance: bmanc_s

Statutory Paternity Pay: bpact_s

Winter Fuel Allowance: boaht_s

Contribution-based Jobseeker's Allowance: bunct_s

Scottish Child Winter Heating Assistance (from 2020): bchht_s

Scottish Carer's Allowance Supplement (from 2018): bcrdicm_s

Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (2020 and 2021 with Covid-19 shocks): bwkmcee_s

Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (2020 and 2021 with Covid-19 shocks): bwkmcse_s

non-simulated non-means-tested non-pension benefits: bedes + bedsl + bdioa + bdisc + bdimb + bdiscwa + bdimbwa + bdict01 + bdict02 + bdiwi + bcrdi + bdisv + bhlwk + buntr + bot

Student payments: bedes

Student Loan: bedsl

Attendance allowance: bdioa

Disability Living Allowance: bdisc

Disability Living (mobility) Allowance: bdimb

Personal Independence Payment living allowance: bdiscwa

Personal Independence Payment mobility: bdimbwa

Incapacity Benefit: bdict01

Contributory Employment and Support Allowance: bdict02

Industrial injuries pension: bdiwi

Carer's Allowance: bcrdi

Severe Disablement Allowance: bdisv

Statutory Sick Pay: bhlwk

Training Allowance: buntr

Other non-means-tested benefits: bot

Pensions: ils_pen = boact00 + boactcm + boawr + bsuwd

Base State pension: boact00

Second State Pension: boactcm

War pension: boawr

Widow's pension: bsuwd

Filter.Name: FilterAdults
Filter.FormulaString: !(DATA_VAR[@age]<16 | ((DATA_VAR[@age]<20 & DATA_VAR[@dec]>0 & DATA_VAR[@dec] < 6) & DATA_VAR[@dms]!=2)) && !((DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeMale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 1) || (DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeFemale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 0))

Filter.Name: FilterAdultsActive
Filter.FormulaString: !(DATA_VAR[@age]<16 | ((DATA_VAR[@age]<20 & DATA_VAR[@dec]>0 & DATA_VAR[@dec] < 6) & DATA_VAR[@dms]!=2)) && !((DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeMale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 1) || (DATA_VAR[@age] >= DATA_VAR[@PensionAgeFemale] && DATA_VAR[@dgn] == 0)) && DATA_VAR[@ilsEarns] > 0

Action.FormulaString: DATA_VAR[@bmact_s] + DATA_VAR[@bmanc_s] + DATA_VAR[@bpact_s] + DATA_VAR[@boaht_s] + DATA_VAR[@bunct_s] + DATA_VAR[@bchht_s] + DATA_VAR[@bcrdicm_s] + DATA_VAR[@bwkmcee_s] + DATA_VAR[@bwkmcse_s]

DATA_VAR[@bedes] + DATA_VAR[@bedsl] + DATA_VAR[@bdioa] + DATA_VAR[@bdisc] + DATA_VAR[@bdimb] + DATA_VAR[@bdiscwa] + DATA_VAR[@bdimbwa] + DATA_VAR[@bdict01] + DATA_VAR[@bdict02] + DATA_VAR[@bdiwi] + DATA_VAR[@bcrdi] + DATA_VAR[@bdisv] + DATA_VAR[@bhlwk] + DATA_VAR[@buntr] + DATA_VAR[@bot]

Page.Name: FiscalOverview
Page.Title: Market incomes and fiscal overview
Page.Subtitle: Yearly, million, currency as defined in model output
Page.Description: The table shows total annual amounts and number of income recipients/tax payers of the specified tax-benefit system(s). It provides an overview of market incomes as well as the fiscal policies covered in UKMOD.

Row.Name: Government revenue through direct taxes and national insurance contributions
Government expenditure on benefits and tax credits

Page.Name: Poverty
Page.Title: Basic poverty indices
Page.Description: These tables show the poverty headcount of the total population and selected sub-population groups as well as the poverty gap and the poverty line (in currency per week). Tables toward the lower half of this sheet report BHC poverty indices based on a poverty line evaluated for the entire UK population. These tables are designed to facilitate regional analysis, in conjunction with policy "ukpovertyline" of the policy spine. The policy "ukpovertyline" is turned off by default. This policy should be turned on, along with the respective regional limitation, if the associated tables are of interest.

Table.Title: 2.1 Poverty indicators (BHC income)

Row.Name: Poverty Gap
Row.Tooltip: Difference between the median equivalised disposable income of people at-risk-of-poverty and poverty line, as a percentage of poverty line.

Row.Name: Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Row.Name: Poverty Line AHC
Row.Title: Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Page.Name: Inequality
Page.Title: Basic Inequality Indices
Page.Description:
The tables here report the Gini index and S80/20 indicator for selected income concepts:

·   The comparison of the original income with the original income after taxes shows to what extent taxes contribute to redistribution.

·   The comparison of the original income plus public pensions after taxes with the original income after taxes shows the role of public pensions for redistribution.

·   The comparison of disposable income with original income shows the extent of income redistribution performed by the tax-benefit system as a whole (incl. National Insurance contributions and benefits beyond public pensions).

The calculated indexes are income concept and system-specific and are all equivalised at the household level. The definition of the top and bottom 20% is always based on equivalised household disposable income.

Table.Title: 3.1 Inequality indices by income definition (BHC income)

Column.Name: Gini
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Column.Name: S80/S20
Column.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: ils_origy: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) less private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income plus Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: ils_dispy: Original income + Benefits (including state pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Table.Title: 3.2 Inequality indices by income definition (AHC income)

Column.Name: Gini
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Column.Name: S80/S20
Column.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: ils_origy: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) less private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: ils_dispy: Original income + Benefits (including state pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions - Housing Costs.

Page.Name: MeanEqIncomeHH
Page.Title: Mean equivalised household income disaggregation
Page.Description: The table shows the mean equivalised household income (disposable & original) of the total population and selected sub-population groups. The last two rows of each table show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

Table.Title: 4.1 Income averages by population decile (BHC income)

Column.Name: Disposable Income
Column.Tooltip: ils_dispy: Original income + Benefits (including state pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Column.Name: Original Income
Column.Tooltip: ils_origy: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) less private transfers paid to other households.

Column.Name: Earnings
Column.Tooltip: ils_earns: Employee and self-employment earnings.

Column.Name: Benefits
Column.Tooltip: ils_ben: All state welfare benefits including state pensions.

Column.Name: Taxes
Column.Tooltip: ils_tax: All direct taxes including devolved income taxes and council taxes.

Column.Name: NICs
Column.Tooltip: ils_sicdy: Employee, self-employed, and other National Insurance Contributions.

Column.Name: Simulated benefits as a share of all benefits
Simulated taxes as a share of all taxes

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Table.Title: 4.2 Income averages by population decile (AHC income)

Column.Name: Disposable Income
Column.Tooltip: ils_dispy: Original income + Benefits \(including state pensions\) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions - Housing Costs.

Column.Name: Original Income

Page.Name: SharesIncome
Page.Title: Income Shares
Page.Subtitle: received/paid by each population group
Page.Description: The tables here report the share of unequivalised household income and income components received or paid by each population subgroup. Where population subgroups are mutually exclusive and account for the entire population, then shares should sum to 100%. The tables answer the question of how much income or income component is concentrated in each population subgroup, revealing who receives the highest share of income support and who pays the highest share of taxes and national insurance contributions.

Table.Title: 6.1 Income shares by decile group (BHC income)

Column.Name: Disposable Income
Column.Tooltip: ils_dispy: Original income + Benefits (including state pensions) – Taxes – National Insurance Contributions.

Page.Description: The table gives background information on the household composition by presenting the average household size of different decile groups (based on the equivalised household disposable income) and the average number of children, working-age adults and elderlies. The last row gives the same information for the population at-risk-of-poverty.

Page.Description: The table shows the cut-off points of equivalised (household and benefit unit) disposable income for each decile group as well as the poverty line.

Row.Name: Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Page.Name: IndirectTaxes
Page.Title: Indirect taxes
Page.Description: UKMOD indirect taxes: this template reports summary statistics for three indirect taxes generated by the TCO add-on: ad valorem excise, specific excise, and value added taxes. Ad valorem excise is expressed as a percentage of producer prices, and is traditionally applied to cigarettes in the UK. Specific excise is expressed as a value per physical unit of consumption, and is traditionally applied to alcohol, tobacco, and liquid fuel products in the UK. Value added taxes are expressed as a percentage of consumer prices inclusive of excise, and is applied to a broad range of commodities in the UK. All tables report population household averages defined as £ per annum per household member.

Table.Title: 9.1 Average indirect taxes by population decile (£ per annum per household member)

Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income before housing costs.

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Page.Name: TaxIncentiveStats
Page.Title: Tax Incentives for Employment
Page.Description:
UKMOD Tax Incentives: this template provides summary statistics for three measures of the tax incentives for employment that are generated by the BVR add-on: marginal tax rates (MTRs), net replacement rates (NRRs) and participation tax rates (PTRs). MTRs report the effective tax rate applied to the last unit of currency earned from employment. NRRs report the proportional impact on disposable income of moving from employment to unemployment. PTRs report the average effective tax rate applied to employment income. All measures are calculated on data projected for each individual with some employment income described by the input data (ils_earns > 0).

The reported statistics average only over those individuals for whom the respective statistic (MTR, NRR, or PTR) was calculated. For example, a population comprised of 100 individuals, might be divided into 10 deciles, each comprised of 10 individuals, ranked in order of ascending household disposable income. If an MTR was calculated for only 3 individuals in the lowest decile, then the respective decile average would be obtained by averaging only over those three individuals.
